Title: Reeves weighs tech tax overhaul to avert US tariffs
Description:
Reeves weighs tech tax overhaul to avert US tariffs

UK considers changes to tech tax to avoid US tariffs

The UK government is exploring potential adjustments to its digital services tax (DST) to avert further tariffs from the US, Rachel Reeves confirmed.

The DST, which targets global tech heavyweights like Meta, Google and Amazon, has raised around £800m a year since its introduction in 2020.

Yet, with President Donald Trump set to announce new tariffs on the 2nd April, the UK is reportedly mulling changing the tax in exchange for a carve out from the duties Trump had threatened to impose on most of the UK’s trading partners.

Addressing the situation, Reeves said: “We need to get the balance right. We don’t want British exporters facing higher tariffs.”

She also said that the UK would continue to make sure tech firms pay taxes where they operate, while aiming to maintain fair trade relations with the US.

Yet, the proposal faced sharp criticism.

Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey condemned the idea of hanging UK tax policy to placate Trump.

Speaking at his party’s spring conference in Harrogate, Davey warned: “Changing the UK’s tax policy to appease Donald Trump and Elon Musk is a dangerous path. Appeasement never works with bullies, and it doesn’t work with Trump. Look at what he’s already done with British steel tariffs”.

His comments reflect growing concern that Labour’s approach to Trump could undermine the UK’s ability to assert its financial independence.

“Now Labour’s even talking about scrapping Britain’s tax on social media giants”, he added.

While Labour officials, including Reeves, have not ruled out changing the DST to secure favourable trade terms, the opposition argues that such concessions could lead to long term harm.

Business secretary Jonathan Reynolds has been in Washington this week discussing trade issues, while tech secretary Peter Kyle has also been in the US, promoting the UK as a hub for AI investment.

Title: IPL: The cricket sensation causing a betting bonanza
Description:
IPL: The cricket sensation causing a betting bonanza

Cricket’s biggest show returned this weekend with the 18th season of the Indian Premier League (IPL) getting underway in Kolkata.

Cricket’s biggest show returned this weekend with the 18th season of the Indian Premier League (IPL) getting underway in Kolkata.

And while online betting is restricted in India – to such categories as the lottery and horse racing – there’s a growing international gambling market interested in the Twenty20 league.

Ironically the Chennai Super Kings and Rajasthan Royals were once suspended from the competition – in 2016 and 2017 – following a spot-fixing and controversy.

Global betting giant Entain tells City AM that 90 per cent of IPL bets placed in their international markets are in-play, with just 10 per cent wagered pre-match.

Last year’s competition saw the highest average first innings score, 191, with punters often betting at the half-way point.

Andrew Harriott, group head of cricket betting, says: “Generally, the two biggest factors for those looking to bet on cricket are: high run-scoring feats and record-breaking chases.

“The IPL delivers both of these in abundance.”

The betting breakdown

Entain’s Global Sportsbook reveals that 40 per cent of Indian Premier League bets in 2024 went on match betting while nearly 15 per cent went on next over runs, 12 per cent on team runs and eight per cent on player runs. In total 90 per cent of bets happen after the first innings.

Read more Best Football Betting Sites UK in March 2025

The spread of bets appears to be pretty fluid in the IPL, and with a number of the teams now having minority or majority stakes in Hundred franchises there could be some affiliation built between fans in the UK and clubs across the subcontinent.

But the outcome can be a toss-up, with last year’s games seeing a near 50-50 split between winners who batted first and winners who battered second.

Added Harriott: “Cricket is more complex than most sports for bookmakers in that it has a third dimension, because of how much the pitch can impact a winning score.

“This can be challenging and leave us feeling like meteorologists at times.”

IPL changes

The IPL has, too, had three different winners in three years, with the Kolkata Knight Riders, Chennai Super Kings and Gujarat Titans all lifting the trophy.

And the Titans did it in their first season in the expanded tournament in 2022, the first case of a first season victory since Rajasthan Royals’ 2008 win in the IPL’s first ever iteration.

Their owners were private equity giants CVC Capital Partners but they’ve sold a majority stake to Torrent Group for an estimated $575m, valuing the franchise at over $850m.

There’s a lot of money hovering around the IPL, whether that be in the value of the teams or in the betting markets. But how will the cards fall this year? We’ll have to wait and see.

Title: Chancellor defends budget choices ahead of Spring statement
Description:
Chancellor defends budget choices ahead of Spring statement

Chancellor defends budget choices and civil service spending cut

Chancellor Rachel Reeves has defended the government’s recent budget decisions, claiming they were necessary for economic stability amid uncertain global conditions.

In an interview with BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg on Sunday, Reeves emphasised the importance of making difficult choices to ensure long term fiscal responsibility.

“There are always going to be costs for every choice you make, but there are also costs for irresponsibility”, Reeves said, ahead of Wednesday’s Spring statement.

“I did the responsible thing in the Budget. It required difficult choices but now, in the changing and uncertain world we’re in, we have economic stability.”

Reeves outlined several achievements stemming from the government’s policies, which she claimed have helped restore confidence in the markets.

These include maintaining non-negotiable fiscal rules, reducing debt as a share of GDP from record levels inherited from the previous government, and the Bank of England’s recent decision to lower interest rates.

The Chancellor also highlighted that wages have risen almost twice the rate of inflation in recent months, benefiting workers across the country.

While acknowledging the need for further action, Reeves said that the government’s focus on stability and reform would bring about growth, without relying on tax hikes.

Read more Reeves is gearing up for a blame game

“We have more to do, but my goal is to bring back the growth without asking people to pay more”, she added.

A major component of Reeves’ plan to reduce government spending is a commitment to cutting civil service costs by 15 per cent by the end of this parliamentary term, she told the BBC.

She outlined how government had increased its administrative and back office functions during the pandemic, but argued that the size of civil service hasn’t been scaled back since.

To address this, every government department has been asked to rank their spending priorities, ensuring resources are allocated accordingly.

“We want to put more money into things that are important for citizens, and less on things that are just not necessary”.

No zero-based review of government spending has been conducted since 2007, a review which Reeves sees as crucial to ensure effective spending.

She reiterated: “I’m determined to bring back the growth that is the prize on offer, alongside the stability and reform needed to deliver it”.

Title: I earned 6 digits, was released at 58-and I can't find a job
Description:
Pete Petersen

Pete Petersen, 58, has difficulty finding work after being released in a company. Petersen said that his age and salary ideas could make his job search in the employee sector more difficult. Despite savings and severance payments, he cannot yet rest, said Petersen.

This essay is based on a conversation with Pete Petersen, 58, who has been looking for a job since February 2024 after being released from his company. Petersen spent a large part of his professional career in the department for consumer goods and health of a pharmaceutical company. He suspects that his age and salary ideas have affected his chances of a job in the area of ​​employees. His statements were revised for reasons of length and clarity.

I live in Hingham, Massachusetts. I was raised by two parents who grew up in more difficult conditions. I grew up in a lifestyle, which one would probably call a high middle class in a city of the upscale middle class. I was not as economical as my father, but when I spent money, I had a guilty conscience.

I visited the University of Massachusetts and made my bachelor's degree in communication because I wanted to go to the film and television industry. For a long time I worked with people from the industry who lived in tiny apartments in New York City at the age of 35 and hardly got a penny. I saw all my friends were doing well and how they enjoyed themselves, so I finally moved back to Boston and started a career in sales.

I joined the then Smithklin Beecham company, a manufacturer of health products. I came up with the idea that it would take three years, and then I would look for another place to earn my millions. Thirty years later, in 2019, when GSK merged with Pfizer, my career was over there.

A long career

I started sales at GSK, went from business to shop, spoke to the people in the corridors, spoke to the managers about the design of the expenses and made sure that our products were in stock. I got to know the business from PIKE by drove to the shops on Saturday morning to upgrade them. Then I headed a team that looked after regional supermarket chains.

In the early 2000s it was more about data analysis. My boss encouraged me to take a very analytical job. I switched to the care of national customers, in my case to the US pharmacy chain CVS. I went there and fell in love with the work. I was able to lock myself up in the basement for three days and delve into the data to find out how our business developed and where we failed with customers.

In 2019 we had these meetings, and I always had to laugh because everyone said: "Who will be released?" I showed them the gray in my beard and said, "My time came" because I was quite expensive. I was right, and the job cuts came in December 2019. In March 2020, hell was going on, so I was looking for a job during this time.

After all, I ended up in a brokerage sales that had worked for regional food chains. That was then dissolved. I switched to a company that produced a cannabis sleeping agent. The branding was great and it was a dream result. I also invested in a brewery with a former colleague and helped my wife's business.

I thought I would be 62 years old and sell the product while I still earn six digits, and I would design the end of my career as I would never have dreamed.

Although I was successful in building the company, the job ended abruptly and unexpectedly with the discovery of financial misconduct by the managing director and his tragic death shortly afterwards. I was unemployed in February.

A year of unemployment

At the beginning of the process, there were some options that I didn't notice. When I applied for jobs and some of the salary packages were much lower than I wanted, I thought: 'I have a daughter for whom I just paid for college, and I have a son who studies.' There is also a little ego.

I talked to an old colleague who was similar who then ended up with a management consultancy and got along well, but he was never as successful as with GSK. I have learned that you have to stop looking at jobs as you would have done at 39. You have to start asking yourself which jobs I can do that correspond to my skills that motivate me to get up in the morning that get my brain going and cover my costs. If you are looking for the unicorn, you will be unpatted with many opportunities to find it.

At this stage of my career, I have the feeling that the puzzle part has to be right if you want to hire someone my age. If you set me at the age of 40, it would be like a puzzle with which you take a part and it looks like it would fit and it is close enough.

I am not afraid of technological changes because I grew up at a time when they quickly accomplished. But I have the feeling that after a year I lost the connection without work. Will I go to work and not even recognize what people do? Did it develop so quickly?

The best scenario I have seen is perhaps ten to 15 percent below my previous basic content, but there are places that are 25 to 40 percent below my previous basic content, even more if you look at the overall package.

Nevertheless, I applied to some CEOs and companies, but in the end they rejected them. If you hire exactly the same person at the age of 40 who can contribute to the growth of the company, you could work with it for at least six to eight years. But if you look at someone at my age, you wonder if he will go back to the moment when he builds up a solid network in the area in which he has not yet worked.

Age discrimination is real, but it is not about a bunch of people sitting around and saying, 'We don't hire the older ones'. You would like to bring experience to the company, but you weigh all the factors. I think they perceive me as someone who is at the end of his career. But if I worked in a company in which I had a boss who gets up every morning and treated myself as I was treated when I did an apprenticeship in my twenties, it would not be as practical for me.

I was very good at dealing with personal finances and saved a good sum of money so that I could survive this special storm. GSK paid me a very good severance payment, so I don't have to worry about things like health care. But I know that it could be devastating for someone who earns a third or half of what I earn in such a situation.

In theory, I could retire in November, but I would live with half of the budget that I hoped for, which would change my lifestyle significantly. I have made plans all my life and I did the right thing by saving me, and that really thrown me back from this plan.

Title: AI in the personality test: so differently tick chatt and gemini
Description:
According to a leading personality test, AI models can have different personalities. Getty Images

The DISC model is a personality test for the workplace in which the behavior is divided into four areas.

A DISC provider tested the most popular chatbots, including Chatgpt and Gemini.

The chatbots seem to have different personalities, which could affect the dynamics at the workplace.

Chatgpt from Openai is confident and positive, but, if you drive it to the top, can also be manipulative. Google's Gemini is a good listener, but maybe needs a little encouragement to say what he really thinks.

This emerges from the disc, a popular personality test for the workplace that some companies now use to integrate AI models into their workforce.

The test was developed by the American psychologist William Moulton Marston, who already dealt with basic questions about human behavior in the 1920s.

In contrast to his contemporaries Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung, who examined people with mental disorders, Marston examined how people interacted in good intellectual condition with others and their surroundings. It is also attributed to the invention of an early version of the lie detector.

Marston finally came to the conclusion that human behavior can be divided into four categories and presented the discperteness model in a book in 1928. Disc stands for the English equivalents of dominance, influence, steadiness and conscientiousness. And Marston viewed her as the four "primary emotions" that control human behavior.

Since then, Marston's model has been formalized in assessments that are now used by Fortune 500 companies, government agencies and universities. The questions that are often asked in the form of statements are, for example, "I am motivated by performance and authority" or "I am mostly right", and the participants answer, depending on how much they agree.

Ultimately, the test participants are assigned to one of 12 types based on their most dominant properties. Someone who receives a D for "dominance" could be described as direct and strong -willed. Someone who receives a DC for "Dominance Conscientation" (dominance and conscientiousness) may be more meticulous and is characterized by critical thinking.

Since companies accelerate the introduction of AI, employees use generative AI to write emails, collect ideas and carry out research. You could see chatbots like Chatgpt as a competent but neutral interlocutor for your thoughts. But these models may not be so neutral.

Online Disc Profile, a provider of Disc, conducted reviews of the most popular AI chatbots. It turned out that Chatgpt from Openaai and Copilot from Microsoft are both di types (Dominance influence ”). These types are known to be enforceable and result-oriented and have a sense of urgency. In the worst case, they can also be manipulative.

Google Gemini and China's Deepseek are a combination of S, C and I and can be classified as "steadiness" types that are less common. These types are more stable and stable and tend to be a good listener. They are characterized by the fact that they give others the feeling of being supported, but they also tend to avoid conflicts.

Some companies should consider how the dynamics in the workplace change when employees communicate several hours a week with a supportive but conflict -shy chat bot alongside their teammates.

According to Sarah Franklin, CEO of Lattice, a platform for the management of employee performance and engagement, teams suddenly become a bit like the management of the characters from Star Wars.

"You have Princess Leia, who leads the rebel command, and she has to do Luke Skywalker together with R2-D2, the robot, along with Han Solo, together with Chewbacca, and then you have C-3PO, another robot, and you all have to coordinate," she said business insider. "This is exactly what we are doing at the moment. We have to be able to work together, but you also need a mission control."

Lattice relies on disc as an internal assessment to "reduce conflicts and improve work" Some employees have already trained chatbots on their disc style, says Mollie West Duffy, director of learning and development at Lattice, to BI by email.

According to Duffy, employees can then ask this bots like: "I am a type C and work with a type D on a cross -functional project. How should I give the other person feedback in the face of their style?"

The platform does not use the work assessment data from its 5,000 customers, which include Openai, Anthropic and E3, but Duffy said that this is something that Lattice is considering for the future. Managers could possibly receive tailor-made feedback tips based on the disc profiles of their direct employees. Or the platform could suggest personalized growth areas.

"We have to have a system in which the AI ​​exists as an employee with transparency, responsibility and management," said Franklin.

Title: He researches whether fewer calories improves longevity - his diet
Description:
James White/Getty

The doctor James White researches to what extent a reduced calorie intake can extend life. He himself reduces calories in his own diet - in a safe and sustainable way. In an interview with Business Insider, White explains his routine.

How many calories do I have to take for a long life - and how much sport should I do? James White deals with these questions as a doctor at Duke University in the US state of North Carolina.

If we reduce our calorie intake, this triggers low stress in the body. As a result, some processes are going to remove the markers of aging from our DNA, explains White in an interview with Business Insider. Research assumes that our cells in old age will work efficiently.

In a study, White and his team found that mice that consumed comparatively 30 to 40 percent fewer calories lived 40 percent longer. This corresponds to a person's life expectancy by another 30 years, says White.

But people are not mice. Such studies are more likely to provide proof of concept for further research than that their results can be transferred to us.

In a separate two -year study, where White also worked, 220 healthy participants who did not suffer from obesity took about 100 to 200 calories a day than they would normally do. Her cardiometabolic health improved - as did the pace of her biological aging. This was measured using markers in the blood, such as the proportion of white blood cells and the change in genes.

However, there is no sufficient evidence that a calorie restriction contributes to the fact that we live longer.

Instead of thinking about how many calories he consumes, White addresses his research results to his life by eating nutritious foods that tend to contain fewer calories. He also tries to keep his sporting routine because he tends to eat healthier when he feels "eating for one purpose".

White told about other lifestyle decisions that he made in the hope of a longer life.

Eat enough calories to keep a "healthy" weight

White does not believe that people have to greatly reduce their calorie intake in order to use the potentially life -prolonging advantages, especially older people who should focus on maintaining muscle mass. Instead, he tries to keep an "healthy" weight in his opinion, in which he has an optimal body composition by not eating too much.

"You have to find a secure basic value for your body for calorie consumption, in which you do not increase. If you want to save a few hundred calories every now and then, it is okay," he said, quoting a study published in the magazine Lancet Diabetes & Endocrinology in 2019.

It stated that healthy, non -obese participants aged 21 to 50, who restricted their calorie intake by an average of 11.9 percent for two years, rarely had cardiometabolic diseases and better blood pressure values ​​and higher insulin sensitivity.

"But you don't have to constantly restrict the calorie intake for years," he said. "Even if you only restrict calorie consumption by a small percentage on a few days a week, health benefits will be shown in our investigations".

It is important to know that calorie -reduced diets are not suitable for people under the age of 18, pregnant women, breastfeeding or people with eating disorders, Katherine Gomez, a registered nutritionist, told BI.

Catherine Falls Commercial/Getty Images

Cardio and strength training

Even a slight increase in physical activity can have "enormous advantages for health and durability", says White.

He trains five or six days a week and does both cardiovascular and strength exercises to maintain the muscles, muscle function and endurance. He lifts weights and goes for 45 minutes for an hour to walk, jog or ride bike.

"But there is a lot of literature that says that three times a week is very effective," he says. A meta -analysis of over 30 million people without previous illnesses published in the British Journal of Sports Medicine in the British Journal of Sports Medicine showed the risk of participants to die from chronic diseases such as cancer and heart diseases.

Eat lean protein and lots of vegetables

White usually focuses on the number of calories he consumes by using calorie measuring apps on his cell phone, and not on what he eats, but he prefers to prefer lean proteins, vegetables and healthy fats.

He also tries to restrict carbohydrates, especially processed, since it is easier to overeat from them.

The Mediterranean diet, which follows similar principles, was chosen by the US News & World Report the eighth year in a row as a healthiest diet. It is rich in vegetables, fruits, whole grains and legumes and contains little processed food and added sugar.

Stress reduction through more sleep

"It is very easy to squeeze into a schedule of working, in which you work constantly, sleep little and feel stressed as a whole," says White.

So he tries to get eight hours of sleep, which helps him to reduce stress, he says.

"Stress is inevitable, but sleep is a good way to relax," he said. "Sleep and stress are a constant process that you have to deal with and listen to your body."

BI has already reported how a doctor who specializes in anti-aging reduces his stress level every morning.

Title: I owe my big tech career to a book-3 important lessons
Description:
Courtesy of Jigyasa Grover

Jigyasa Grover attributes the book "The Secret" to be responsible for her professional success in the areas of AI and technology. The book has encouraged them to set themselves ambitious goals and to imagine how they can achieve them. Grover emphasizes that the combination of visualization with hard work and cooperation leads to success.

The 29-year-old Jigyasa Grover completed an internship at Meta and worked for over four years at X as a senior machine learning engineer. She was discontinued as a senior data scientist at the startup Faire in San Francisco before she started her current full -time position as head of AI and research on Bordo Ai.

She is also a member of the Developer Advisory Board from Google and AI consultant at Diem. She has reached all of this since she completed computer science in 2018.

In addition to her hard work, Grover said to Business Insider that Rhonda Byrne's self-help bestseller “The Secret” from 2006 influenced her approach to achieving higher career goals.

Grover read "The Secret" in 10th grade

She said that "The Secret" had a "profound influence" on her approach to determining professional goals and overcoming self -doubt.

"It is not about manifesting things in a magical way, but about developing a strong way of thinking that stimulates action," said Grover. “The book was particularly helpful because it taught me to set concrete, realistic goals and then implement them

Here are three strategies that Grover used from "The Secret" to improve their attitude and achieve great goals on their big tech career.

1. Focus on dreams that are taken far, not just on what seems realistic

Before she read "The Secret", Grover only concentrated on the objective of what appeared to be "realistic". Byrne's book encouraged her to have larger dreams and set goals based on their true wishes, even if they initially appeared far.

In addition to her interest in working with artificial intelligence and machine learning, Grover had another goal of which she believed that she could not achieve it so soon: to write a book.

In 2019 she began to be a published author with the help of techniques that she had learned from "The Secret" to "really concentrate on her vision". During her daily walks, she often thought about it.

"I imagined not only to hold the finished book in my hand, but also to explain complex concepts of machine learning in a clear and understandable way," said Grover. "I imagined how I would break down the process of preparing data that I had learned through my work on Twitter and my research on UC San Diego."

After she started visualization, according to Grover, the possibility of a book publication arose much faster than she expected. From the initial concept to the self -published book, less than a year passed.

"Since I always had this topic in mind, I quickly took the opportunity to write a book, and the universe showed me a way that I could not have imagined," said Grover.

This path was to find a co-author with additional specialist knowledge and unexpected time to realize a book project. Grover was contacted by some publishers for possible book projects in 2019, but at the time she lacked the time and the bandwidth to pursue these options.

"When the pandemic broke out, the resulting shift of my schedule and my living conditions created the perfect time window for me to publish a book on my own conditions myself," she said.

2. Imagine that you have already achieved your goals

Grover explained that an important part of "The Secret" is to imagine that the desired result has already been achieved. "Before every project, I make sure that I firmly believe in my ability to realize the project," she said.

Whenever she offers an opportunity, be it in a fast-moving start-up environment or in a demanding technical environment at Big Tech, she imagines how she does well in this role. "This really helps me to calm down my nerves, to keep it and achieve my goal," said Grover.

She used this method inspired by Secret during the post-acquisition chaos at X, where it worked from 2019 to 2023.

"That was a big challenge: massive layoffs, uncertainty about the future, and important stakeholders were gone, which threatened the entire product roadmap," said Grover. "It was hard to see my talented teammates, so I started to imagine how I would emerge strengthened from this situation."

Grover stayed with X for a few more months after the takeover and experienced most of the layoffs. "I saw it as an opportunity to lead through changes, to support my team in an incredibly difficult time and to prove my resistance," she said.

With the focus on deep breath and "This will also pass", Grover introduced itself to use the turbulence of the situation: it becomes more adaptable, build closer relationships with the few remaining teams and learns to deal with the constant adversity.

Every evening before going to bed, she takes 15 minutes to distract herself from the work of the day and concentrate on a certain challenge, trying to see the overall picture and imagine what she can do.

She writes down three specific technical or creative challenges that she wants to tackle and dismantles the big chunk of work into bite -sized pieces. Then she introduces herself to how it solves every single task, concentrating on the positive effects and celebrating the achievement of every milestone.

When doubts sneak in with tricky areas, Grover plans to cope with them the next day and encourages their belief in their focused vision.

3. Go beyond the mere visualization to inspire you

Grover said that the secret to maximize these methods should go beyond the visualization of the desired result. She recommends believing that you can achieve something and use the visualization as a springboard to work hard, work well with others and maintain a strong vision.

"I really believe that the combination of technical expertise and attitude to implement these skills has only made my success possible," said Gover.

Grover believes that the balance between practical technical skills in the field of mechanical learning and its unshakable belief in the success of the project ultimately caused her to publish her book. She believes that "The Secret" has also indirectly contributed to getting her current job.

When she applied to Bordo Ai, the company was still in a very early stage of developing a new kind of AI solution. "The Secret" inspired her to imagine how the company could succeed in revolutionizing data analysis with AI. "It helped me to cultivate a way of thinking that made it possible for me to see opportunities where others may see risks," said Grover.

Title: Career in M&A: These skills must show your resume
Description:
Christian Saxenhammer is the founder and managing director of the M&A-Boutique Saxenhammer. He has successfully advised more than 400 transactions. Saxenhammer / Getty Images

M&A is the supreme discipline in the financial sector - highly complex deals, strategic decisions and negotiations at the highest level. But what does it take to be successful in this demanding industry? In this text, M&A consultant Christian Saxenhammer shares his experiences and gives valuable insights into how you can get started with M&A, which skills really count and how you can secure a place in the leading consulting houses in the long term. M&A is considered the most demanding discipline in the financial sector that not only requires analytical skills, but also strategic thinking and negotiation skills, says Christian Saxenhammer. The former investment banker is the founder and managing director of the M&A-Boutique Saxenhammer. He has successfully advised more than 400 transactions. Success in M&A depends less on numbers alone, but also on soft skills such as empathy and communication skills in order to successfully complete deals.

"Mergers & Acquisitions" (M&A) is considered the royal discipline in the financial sector - high deals of deal, complex negotiations and the direct influence on corporate strategies make them one of the most exciting and demanding career paths in the financial sector.

But how does it come about? What skills are required? And what do young talents have to bring to be successful in the long term?

No job for everyone - my entry into M&A

At the age of 21 I sold our family business - an experience that not only changed my life, but also revealed my calling. I was confronted early with complex negotiations, strategic decisions and the dynamics of deal making.

The M&A industry is not a 9-to-5 job Christian Saxenhammer

Since then I know: M&A is not a profession, but a passion - but not for everyone.

Success in this area requires much more than analytical excellence. Strategic thinking, negotiation skills and entrepreneurship are essential.

The industry is not a 9-to-5 job-it requires high use, resilience and a tireless drive. If you want to successfully complete deals, you not only have to analyze numbers, but also convince investors and entrepreneurs.

The underestimated success factor: mentors and learning-by-thoing

In M&A there are no classic school books that prepare for every situation. Theoretical knowledge is important, but the true learning curve only begins when you are in the middle of complex deals. It is therefore crucial to find a mentor or sparring partner early, which reports from his own experience.

In my career, I benefited enormously from working with experienced dealmakers that not only gave me technical skills, but also the art of negotiating.

The best M&A consultants are those who are willing to admit mistakes, learn from them and to continuously improve. Anyone who works with the right people right from the start and deliberately goes into challenging situations has a decisive advantage in the long term.

The way to the top m & a houses

The leading M&A consultations often get started through renowned economic universities. WHU, Mannheim, HSG or LSE students have a clear advantage when it comes to securing coveted internships at investment banks, private equity companies or M&A boutiques.

Title: I was in space with Blue Origin - I now look at life differently
Description:
Inkhouse

The technologist Lane Bess looks back on his two space travel with Blue Origin. Bess said that every trip has renewed its meaning for the essentials in life. He called for more visionary investments in space technology and research.

This is a conversation with the veteran of the technology sector Lane Bess. He founded Bess Ventures and is CEO of Deep Instinct, a cyber security company based on Deep Learning. He is also the chairman of Blaize Ai, former CEO of Palo Alto Networks and former COO of ZSCALER. He has no financial connections to Blue Origin.

I have been in space twice in the past three years. Every time I returned with a new awareness of the essentials in life.

My first flight took place in December 2021, my second last February. Every flight only lasted 10 minutes, but the earth looks completely different when you start and when you land.

This time I came back with some questions about the condition of our world. The war has escalated since my first trip. At that time I thought - and still thinking today - that the only limit for what humanity can achieve is our ability to get along.

What I see instead is a hunger for power, a changed perspective of people on politics and people who jeopardize the founding ideas of our constitutional forefathers for things that only favor one country to another.

US President Donald Trump, Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese head of state Xi Jinping should not be the only three people in the world who have a say in how the rest of humanity lives his life.

All of this could think that we should look for a different place, because we will screw it up. We won't colonize Mars so soon, but maybe we have to start with it now.

A lifelong curiosity

I have been fascinated by rockets since childhood. Before I was a teenager, I went to the local craft shop -where I had to lie over my age -to buy these model missile engines (which of course were flammable). I then shared this passion with my son Cameron, who also accompanied me on my first space.

Years later it was also possible for civilians to fly into space. Fortunately, I had left my former cybersecurity companies Palo Alto Networks and Zscaler with great success at this point, so I could afford to offer an auction for a seat at Blue Origin. I also dealt with my family office, Bess Ventures, with investments in space technology.

In 2021, shortly before Thanksgiving, the director for the company and civilian sales of Blue Origin contacted me to attend the third flight. In January of this year I was contacted again when a place for the tenth flight was released.

I can't say exactly how much my last trip cost, but it was a millions. It is clear that my five fellow travelers also achieved a good financial result in life. Richard Scott is a reproduction endocrinologist who sold his company for reproductive medicine, Ivirma, to which private equity company KKR. Elaine Chia Hyde, a physicist, pilot and founder of the media company Chicago Star and the only woman on the trip, had saved it for years to do this.

Before departure, we spent about two and a half days in the classroom. Unlike astronauts who prepare for longer orbital trips, we did not spent time to train in a centrifuge or swim in a tank to understand the weightlessness. This was more about getting to know the technology behind the rocket so that you know how safe it is. However, you can get out of up to two and a half minutes before pulling the landing bridges.

Before the start, we climb into the capsule of the rocket provided for the crew. You don't feel much in the first five to seven seconds because the engine lights. You have earplugs to dampen the sound of the engine, but you still hear a loud knock. Then the capsule is thrown into the air.

In two and a half minutes you cross the Kármán line and realize how thin and fragile the earth's atmosphere is. At that time you are also weightless. I used my GoPro to take the view.

The climb is gentle, but the descent can be bumpy. With such a high gravity acceleration, you are pulled into the seat that you can no longer move - let alone inhale deeply.

After landing, we were received by our families. We encountered champagne and noticed that we were one of a few hundred civilians who had ventured into space.

Billionaires for space travel

I had my first contacts with Jeff Bezos' company Amazon in the nineties when I set up the AT&T internet business as a product manager and Amazon introduced the online sale of books.

I would not say that we are close friends, but I know him well enough to be able to say that his commitment to space and science is sincere. On his ranch he once told me that he felt blessed that he had generated so much wealth with his business that he could really think about things that most people would simply not think about.

There are thousands of billionaires in the world, but only about a dozen who put their money into really future -oriented things. I think every generation needs some of them.

Title: Apple: iPhone customers are waiting for Siri update-and complain now
Description:
From the point of view of some collectors, Apple promised AI tools and not delivered. AP Photo/Ted Shafrey

A Californian law firm sues the Tech Group Apple because the smartphone manufacturer delays the launch of its announced AI functions. The lawsuit said that Apple had deceived the buyers with the promised but not yet delivered features. In March, the company announced that the AI ​​improvements of its assistant Siri are still waiting.

In September last year, Apple had advertised his iPhone 16 with a new Siri update. In March, the company admitted delays in the delivery of artificial intelligence (AI) - and is now exposed to a lawsuit. The accusation: Apple made false promises and deceived customers.

On Wednesday, the law firm Clarkson based in Malibu, based in Malibu California, submitted to the US district court in San Jose for unfair competition. "The consumers are enthusiastic about artificial intelligence. Unfortunately, this meant that Big Tech promised too much and delivered too little," said Timothy Giordano, partner of the law firm Clarkson, in a statement for business insider (BI).

According to the collective suit of numerous iPhone 16-owners, customers are disappointed. Apple "exploited consumers' desire for the latest software and functions for artificial intelligence on their telephones" and not delivered all Apple Intelligence tools that it had announced before the iPhone 16 was released. "

Apple advertises with the first AI-iPhone-and remains behind expectations

Since the market launch in September, the Tech-Riese has been promoting the iPhone 16 as the first of its kind that is “built for artificial intelligence”. The so -called Apple Intelligence is an integral part of the advertising for the device. The technology is only available for the iPhone 15 Pro- or newer models. The iPhone 16 product series begins in Germany at 949 euros.

In a rare step, however, Apple announced at the beginning of the month that Siri's planned AI upgrade should only be there later than expected. The company had demonstrated its update months before the latest iPhone was published. The plaintiffs refer to a commercial from September. In it, the actress Bella Ramsey uses a more personalized Siri version.

Now the company is confronted with the accusation that it has "exaggerated the AI ​​skills. In addition, it has left consumers in the belief that they would buy a device with functions that did not exist or were essentially presented," says the application.

The Tech-Riese demonstrated its Apple Intelligence months before the latest iPhone was published at the Worldwide Developers Conference in June. At that time, Apple presented a AI-controlled iPhone with tools for writing and editing photos, among other Genai functions that were supposed to appear in autumn. Apple Intelligence was introduced in October a month after the iPhone 16 came onto the market.

iPhone 16 with Ki-Siri: Apple wants to catch up with the competition-and exchange personal details

The company is aiming to equate Google, Meta and Microsoft with the AI ​​competition. This wants to boost iPhone sales. However, criticism of the previous results and questions about future developments are not new.

The analyst Benedict Evans, for example, states in a blog post. In it he writes that Apple was always reliable when it came to the launch of upcoming functions. The company will only present new products if they are also delivered. "It never misses such appointments." If Apple had now acted according to this pattern, it would have met its goals and the user could already use the AI ​​today.

The news agency "Bloomberg" reported on Wednesday of a change in staff in the Apple AI department. Accordingly, Mike Rockwell, the co-inventor of the VR glasses Vision Pro, the previous director, John Giannandrea, replaces Siri development.

Apple did not react immediately to our request.

Probably the current lawsuit is not enough to damage the Apple share. But Forrester analyst Dipanjan Chatterjee sees the company in the bredouille. In a statement for BI, he sees a "threat to the market value of Apple", which is unable to deliver a AI-supported Siri program in good time. Apple could no longer hide because the GEMAI chatbots of the competitors are already in use, he said.

Title: Ex-Waymo-CEO: Teslas Robotaxis haben keine Chance gegen Waymo
Description:
Der ehemalige Waymo-CEO John Krafcik erklärte gegenüber Business Insider, dass Waymo im Bereich der Robotertaxis keine Konkurrenten hat, die mit der Größe, Sicherheit und Leistung des Unternehmens mithalten können. Sean Gallup/Getty Images

Der ehemalige Waymo-CEO John Krafcik sagte Business Insider, dass Waymo derzeit keine Konkurrenten habe. Er kritisierte erneut Teslas Kamera-Ansatz für autonomes Fahren. Krafcik sagte auch, dass andere Unternehmen in den USA und China noch hinter Waymo zurückliegen.

Im Jahr 2021, als John Krafcik sich dem Ende seiner Karriere bei Alphabet’s Waymo näherte, wies der CEO Tesla als ernsthaften Konkurrenten im Robotaxi-Wettbewerb zurück. Er bezeichnete Elon Musks Elektrofahrzeugunternehmen als einen Automobilhersteller mit einem „wirklich guten Fahrerassistenzsystem“.

Vier Jahre später bleibt seine Haltung unverändert.

„Tesla strebt seit fast zehn Jahren an, mit Waymo zu konkurrieren, aber sie tun es immer noch nicht“, sagte Krafcik in einer E-Mail-Korrespondenz mit Business Insider (BI). „Sie sind ein Automobilunternehmen mit einem Fahrerassistenzsystem. Sie haben noch keine einzige vollständig autonome, umsatzgenerierende Fahrt geliefert, etwas, das Waymo bereits eine Million Mal im Monat tut.“

Vergangenes Jahr machte Tesla eine auffällige Demonstration seines Robotaxi-Prototyps, Cybercab, einem flachen Coupé ohne Lenkrad, das zwei Passagiere transportieren kann, zusammen mit einem retrofuturistischen, selbstfahrenden Van. Die Wall Street war nicht beeindruckt und auch Krafcik nicht.

„Wenn ein Unternehmen ernsthaft ein sicheres und zugängliches Robotaxi-Geschäft aufbauen wollte, würde es nichts wie das Gezeigte aussehen“, sagte Krafcik im BI-Interview nach der Enthüllung des Cybercab im Oktober.

Krafcik bleibt hochkritisch gegenüber Teslas Robotaxi-Träumen.

In der Branche gibt es viele Stimmen, die sagen, dass sichere und zuverlässige autonome Fahrzeuge Lidar-Sensoren und Kameras benötigen, um ihre Umgebung zu navigieren.

Tesla und sein CEO hingegen setzen auf Kameras allein. Sie hoffen einen autonomen Fahrer einsetzen zu können, ohne die Kosten für die Anbringung von Lidar-Sensoren.

Doch Krafcik weist das Kostenargument zurück.

„Die Kosten für ein robustes Sensorset, einschließlich Lidar, sind auf einer Pro-Meile-Basis trivial. Noch mehr für die Kartierung“, schrieb er. „Und die Sicherheitsvorteile, gemessen an der Reduzierung menschlicher Schäden, sind real und nachweisbar.“

Ein Sprecher von Tesla antwortete nicht auf eine Anfrage zur Stellungnahme.

Der Robotaxi-Wettbewerb

Der ehemalige Waymo-CEO hatte Unternehmen im April 2021 aus nicht näher genannten Gründen verlassen und sitzt jetzt im Vorstand von Rivian. Er glaubt, dass Waymo im Bereich autonomer Fahrdienste weit voraus ist, auch wenn Unternehmen in den USA und China ihre eigenen Robotaxis einsetzen.

Baidus Apollo Go sagte, das Unternehmen habe im vierten Quartal 2024 etwa 1,1 Millionen Fahrten in China gemacht. Zoox, eine Tochtergesellschaft von Amazon, testet weiterhin in San Francisco und Las Vegas. Es plant, den öffentlichen Betrieb in diesen Städten später in diesem Jahr zu starten. Musk hat ebenfalls versprochen, bis Juni vollständig autonome Fahrten in Austin anzubieten.

Waymo sagte, es biete mehr als 200.000 Fahrten pro Woche in seinen Betriebsstädten Los Angeles, Phoenix und San Francisco an. Der Fahrdienst expandiert weiterhin in den USA und hat mit begrenzten Tests in Tokio begonnen.

Lest auch Wegen drohender Zölle: Hyundai investiert mehr als 16 Milliarden Euro in Heimatmarkt

„Im Moment hat Waymo keine Konkurrenz“, sagte Krafcik, der zuvor auch Hyundai Motor America als CEO leitete.

„Große Hoffnungen“

Krafcik sagte, er sei am meisten beeindruckt von Waymos Fortschritten in Bezug auf Skalierung, Sicherheit und Leistung. Deshalb glaubt er, dass Waymo für mindestens die nächsten drei bis fünf Jahre vorne bleiben wird.

„Sie sind das einzige Unternehmen weltweit, das erfolgreich einen verkörperten KI-Ersatz für einen lizenzierten menschlichen Fahrer einsetzt, der in jedes Fahrzeug integriert werden kann – und dies in großem Maßstab mit Drittanbieterdaten, die signifikante Leistungs- und Sicherheitsvorteile gegenüber menschlichen Fahrern bestätigen“, sagte Krafcik.

Ein Sprecher von Waymo antwortete nicht auf eine Anfrage zur Stellungnahme.

Über Zoox sagte Krafcik, er habe „große Hoffnungen“ und schätze „die Sorgfalt, die sie walten lassen, um auf den Markt zu kommen“. Trotzdem sei der Betrieb des Amazon-Unternehmens im Robotaxi-Bereich auf einer kleineren Skala, die eher mit Waymo im Jahr 2018 vergleichbar sei, sagte er.

Über chinesische Konkurrenten nannte Krafcik keine spezifischen Unternehmen. Trotzdem, sagte er BI, sei er skeptisch, dass ihre autonomen Fahrer so gut wie die von Waymo seien, da sie es nicht geschafft hätten, einen Robotaxi-Dienst in den USA zu starten. Zum Beispiel wurde Pony.ai, einem chinesischen Startup, im Mai 2022 wegen mehreren Fahrverstößen die Kalifornien-Genehmigung von der Abteilung für Kraftfahrzeuge entzogen.

Sprecher von Zoox und Pony.ai antworteten nicht auf eine Anfrage zur Stellungnahme.

Die positive Perspektive für Waymo

Der Nordstern für Waymo wird nicht nur ein eigenständiger Fahrdienst sein, sagte Krafcik. Der Ex-Waymo-CEO fügte hinzu, dass er sich vorstellt, dass das Unternehmen einen Abonnementdienst für einen „garantierten Zugang zum Waymo-Fahrer“ und autonome Fahrsoftware anbieten wird, die in großen Lastwagen und privaten Fahrzeugen eingesetzt werden kann.

Einige Analysten erwarten einen Waymo-Börsengang und eine Abspaltung von Alphabet, da das Geschäft voranschreitet.

Gene Munster von Deepwater Asset Management schrieb im November, dass Waymo innerhalb von zwei bis vier Jahren aus Alphabet ausgegliedert werden könne. Bis 2030 könne es möglicherweise mit 350 Milliarden bis 850 Milliarden US-Dollar bewertet werden.

Krafcik, der Waymos Abspaltung in eine unabhängige Tochtergesellschaft von Alphabet im Jahr 2016 überwachte, sagte: „Es gibt keinen Grund zur Eile.“

„Waymo hat eine tiefe, intelligente Gruppe geduldiger Investoren“, sagte er. „Es gibt keinen Grund zur Eile – sie sind nicht wie die anderen Möchtegern-AV-Unternehmen, die öffentliche Märkte anzapfen, um schnell Geld zu bekommen, um zu überleben. Die meisten dieser Unternehmen haben nicht die Technologie, um ihre Versprechen zu erfüllen, und werden scheitern.“

Entrepreneur with a foresight

Shockemöhle was not limited to horses alone. He built up a wide -ranging company portfolio early on, which includes freight forwarders, logistics, feed production, real estate and renewable energies.

Title: After this one question in the interview you should go
Description:
This question in the interview is a warning signal, says Kristine Capek. Getty Images / Olga Rolenko, Collage: Business Insider

According to the personnel consultant Kristine Capek, the key to a successful job interview in competence -based questions, which enable a precise assessment. The question "Why should we hire you?" On the other hand, put the applicants under unnecessary pressure. "The application process is no longer just about a one -sided assessment - rather about getting to know each other at eye level." Instead of pushing the applicants into a sales situation, companies should specifically ask about their motivation - for example: "Why did you apply for this position?"

An interview can decide on the professional future - but often these conversations are anything but ideal. Companies present themselves in detail, applicants lose themselves in irrelevant details, and some questions have a daunting than effective.

Kristine Capek knows the typical stumbling blocks. As the founder and managing director of the personnel consultancy "Ivies", she has been teaching specialists in the pharmaceutical and biotech industry for over 15 years. She gives career tips on Tikkok as a "dieheadhunter". In an interview with Business Insider, she explains what really matters in a successful interview - and what questions should be deterrent.

How does an ideal interview work?

According to Kristine Capek, an ideal interview always starts with small talk. This creates a pleasant atmosphere and relaxes the situation. This is followed by a brief introduction to the company and Hiring management. "But short and concise, because the focus is on the applicant, not the management or the team," emphasizes Capek.

Also read 6 psychological tricks to look more likeable in an interview

"When managers only present themselves for minutes, it is a clear red flag and says a lot about corporate culture." Instead, the conversation should quickly pass to the applicants - this signal real interest on the part of the company.

The perfect self -presentation in the interview: neither too long nor too short

As an applicant, your self -presentation should take between five and ten minutes. No less, nothing more. You should leave out irrelevant details and concentrate on what is really important for the position, the personnel consultant advises. From the beginning, this creates a targeted connection between your own experience and the new position. However, reality often looks different. Capek knows: "Many start with their Abitur - and lose their focus."

Reading I also had over 1000 interviews - this one question should always ask applicants

However, this is not surprising that many companies vote for the first question to applicants very openly. You would say, for example: "Tell something about yourself." Instead, companies should target the interview and ask more specific questions. For example: "Why did you apply for this position? What competencies do you bring with you that enable you for the job?" The key to a successful interview? Competence -based questions.

Why competence -based questions are the key

For a successful interview, it is crucial that companies define in advance exactly which skills are required for the open position. "For example, if negotiation skills are required, one could specifically ask for experience with difficult negotiations," explains Capek. Applicants could specifically explain how they have already used this competence.

As an applicant, on the other hand, you should not only worship past positions. Focus on the skills and strengths you have developed in previous roles and what added value you could offer in your potentially new role.

This question is a red flag in an interview: "Why should we hire you?"

Not every question in the interview makes sense - some could (and should) even put off applicants according to the expert. One of them: "Why should we hire them?" This question is often asked from above, with the unspoken message: convince us first. The application process is no longer just about a one -sided assessment - rather about getting to know each other at eye level.

Reading you also ask no questions in the interview? Why this is a mistake according to HR and which you should at least make

Capek advises companies to formulate the question differently in order to put the applicants less under pressure. For example: "Why did you apply for this position?" This question rather aims at what applicants interested in the position and the company. Unlike the other question, it is not about how well someone can sell. Rather, it is about finding out how well someone is suitable for the open position.

This is how you react confidently to problematic questions in the interview

In one of her Tikok videos, Capek says: "If you as an applicant are asked, why you should be set, then pack your things together and take a tear."

But if that is too dramatic for you, for example, you can answer instead: "I was invited because my qualifications fit the position. I would be happy to explain again which skills I bring with me and how I can bring them in."

Then you could play the ball back and ask your interlocutors whether it is covered with all skills relevant to the position or whether they would like to talk about further qualifications. "This remains the conversation professionally and at eye level," concludes Capek.
